column6: Energy consumption outside of the organization

column7: The offsets we purchase must be seen today and in the future as honest and credible by our people capital and customer markets. We will exclude project types and offsets that we consider to constitute: Ã¢ÂÂ¢ unacceptable risk in terms of sensible stakeholder views on the additionality of the carbon reduction or which carry eligibility or additionality risk in the medium term (including landfill gas and avoided deforestation projects) Ã¢ÂÂ¢ unacceptable risk of abatement overestimation or impermanence Ã¢ÂÂ¢ unacceptable project proponent risk (including beneficial owners other activities, and the risk of exposing IGO to association with exploitation, unethical or unsafe actions, or parties that lack credibility) Ã¢ÂÂ¢ a cause of social, economic, environmental or political harm or reasonable opposition; and Ã¢ÂÂ¢ a possible cause of social disadvantage or inequitable outcomes for location communities or workers.\t
There is no reduction in energy consumption in 2023.

$8.3M was allocated to our decarbonisation fund in FY23, which was designed to facilitate carbon reduction initiatives and projects. The Group's emissions increased during FY23 due to consolidating the Cosmos and Forrestania assets into IGO's emissions portfolio. However, Nova emissions were down 9%, primarily due to the power station fire in December 2022, which resulted in significantly lower power generation until temporary power could be established. I commissioned the new solar farm and battery storage facility at Nova and achieved the first engine-off operation (100% renewable power), a first for an Australian mine site. Progressed Cosmos decarbonisation roadmap, including mine electrification and renewable energy studies

column6: Reductions in energy requirements of products and services
Reductions in energy requirements of products and services
column7: We believe that clean energy, including renewable energy generation, grid-scale energy storage and the electrification of transport, is central to limiting the human causes of climate change.

column6: Interactions with water as a shared resource
column7: In Western Australia, water abstraction is subject to a licence issued by the Department of Water and Environment Regulation (DWER). In FY23, we complied with our licence obligations and actively monitored abstraction and groundwater levels to ensure ongoing compliance.\t

column6: Interactions with water as a shared resource
column7: We are committed to open and transparent dealings with all our stakeholders at IGO. Tax payment is an essential element of our contribution to the economic development of Australia.\t

Our water management plans consider the unique hydrological characteristics of the region, and we work closely with local stakeholders and regulatory bodies to ensure compliance with water allocation and quality standards. We prioritise efficient water use by implementing advanced technologies and practices to minimise consumption and maximise recycling and reuse.\t

column13: The upgraded wastewater treatment plant infrastructure at the Nova Operation allows wastewater to be recycled and used in the concentrate washing process, resulting in further water use efficiencies and decreased groundwater abstraction.\t

column7: The total water discharge is 1,329 megalitres.\t

column6: Operational sites owned, leased, managed in, or adjacent to, protected areas and areas of high biodiversity value outside protected areas
column7: During its feasibility phase, environmental studies at the Nova Operation found 45 vegetation communities and 142 vertebrate fauna species, including 40 reptiles, 82 birds and 20 mammal species. The area surrounding Nova is known to support populations of the Vulnerable (Conservation status) Malleefowl (Leiopoa Ocellata); where ground-disturbing activity is proposed, the area is searched for evidence of the Malleefowl before ground-disturbing activities commencing.

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column7: The Nova and Forrestania Operations are within the GWW, Earth's most extensive, relatively untouched temperate woodland. The GWW covers almost 16M ha and co-exists with more than 300 mines, 5,000 tenements and pastoral leases that cover about 20% of the area.\t

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: IGO works in some of Australia's most unique and remote regions, with significant biodiversity and ecosystems. Our activities must be managed to ensure the conservation of these regions to ensure we maintain our social license to operate. We are committed to contributing to biodiversity conservation and seek to understand and protect the ecosystems in all our operational areas.\t

column7: The three most significant IGO greenfield exploration projects are the Albany-Fraser Orogen (AFO), Paterson and Kimberley, and all three project areas have high biodiversity and are assessed as having high integrity, partly due to their remoteness. The AFO project is located across the Coolgardie woodlands ecoregion, in the GWW, within the Mediterranean Forests, Woodlands & Scrub biome and the Great Victoria Desert ecoregion. Numerous conservation estates coincide with the AFO project. IGO operates with Environmental Management Plans, which set out specific environmental management conditions, as agreed with the relevant regulatory bodies, whenever operating within any conservation estate.

column6: IUCN Red List species and national conversation list species with habitats in areas affected by operations

column13: Climate projections to 2030 were used to discuss potential climate impacts across key mining operation areas. It considered current risks driven by present-day weather and climate conditions and those that may be intensified by future climate change and emerging risks that future climate conditions may drive. The key areas covered by the operation included water, energy, transport/access, equipment and infrastructure, health and safety, land management, and critical supply chain.
column20: Climate Impact Assessment, Future Climate Projections, Risk Identification and Management

column13: Climate change risks are integrated into IGO's company-wide risk identification, assessment and management process. IGO's approach to risk management is governed by our risk management framework, which is aligned with the principles of the International Standard for Risk Management ISO: 31000.\t
column20: Company-wide Risk Integration, ISO Framework Alignment, Risk Management Framework

column13: Our strategy is informed by our winning aspiration to contribute to a better planet for future generations by supplying products critical to the clean energy transition. In this context, climate change-related considerations are embedded into IGO's core strategic activities, planning and decision-making. Our strategic approach to climate change is centred around a) the supply of products critical to a clean energy future, b) reducing our total carbon footprint, and c) building our physical resilience.\t
column20: Clean Energy Supply Chain, Carbon Footprint Reduction, Resilience Building

column8: Supplying Products Critical to Clean Energy
column13: Our strategy is centred on being a globally relevant supplier of products critical to clean energy. IGO's portfolio has been shaped to link to clean power and zero emissions vehicle technologies intrinsically and is therefore strategically aligned to support the goals of the Paris Agreement.\t
column20: Clean Energy Product Portfolio, Paris Agreement Alignment, Sustainable Supply Chain

column8: R&D and trials of emerging technologies
column13: Pro-active engagement in R&D and trials of emerging technologies to support and enable technical progress on creating the net zero mine of the future. IGO is a crucial participant and member of the EMC and Australia's FBICRC, piloting static battery storage and EV trials across the business.\t
column20: R&D Engagement, Emerging Technologies, Technical Progress
